Variation Example: A dragon (devil) carries off a girl (three girls) & kills her brothers when they try to rescue her. After a magic conception (often by swallowing a pea), the mother of the siblings gives birth to a strong son. This son kills the dragon, rescues his sister, & resuscitates his brothers. The envious brothers plan to kill the youngest. But because of his strength he is able to free himself & to punish his brothers.

This type combines various introductory episodes with the two main parts of the “Magic Flight” & the “Forgotten Fian-cée”. Introductory episodes: (1) After a war between birds & quadrupeds, a wounded eagle is cared for by a man. The eagle (its relatives) gives the man a box which he must not open before he arrives at home. The man disobeys & a castle appears. An giant helps the man close the box and, in return, is promised the man’s unborn son. In some variants, a boy is promised to a demon, giant, or devil or the boy promises himself to the demon. Threat-ening him with death, the demon (giant, devil) assigns the youth (often three) impossible tasks (e.g. building a castle in one night, bailing out a pond with a sieve, felling a forest using an axe of glass, capturing a magic horse which he performs with the help of the demon’s daughter. Before the youth can marry the daughter, he must identify her in a group of women (her sisters) who look just like her. (2) A youth watches girls (transformed swans) bathing in a lake & steals the swan dress of one of them. The girl agrees to marry the youth & takes him to her father’s house. (3) A king suffering from leprosy (scabs) captures a prince & feeds him with sweets for forty days, in the hope that the prince’s blood will cure his sickness. The princess falls in love with the foreign youth. Main parts:Magic Flight. The daughter of the demon (king) uses her magical power to flee together with the youth. She leaves magic speaking objects (spittle, blood) behind to deceive her father. Never-theless the flight is discovered & the father follows them. In order to escape, the girl transforms herself & her fiancé into various things or persons (e.g. into rose & thornbush, church & priest, lake & duck), or she throws magic objects (comb, brush, mirror, etc.) which become obstacles in the way of the pursuer. After the third transformation, the pursuer has to give up (dies). In some variants of the Magic Flight two children (brother & sister) flee from a witch (demon, dragon, ogre, witch, wolf, bad step-mother). The youth goes to visit his home & leaves his bride behind. At home he breaks a taboo: Disobeying the bride’s warning, he kisses someone (eats something) & thus forgets his experiences. When the youth is about to marry another woman, the forgotten fiancée reawakens his memory by performing magic actions (paralyses three lovers in embarrassing positions, magically stops the wedding carriage of the new bride, brings a couple of birds who remind the youth of her help, or buys a place for three nights in the bridal bed from her husband’s new bride, & in the third night successfully reawakens his memory . The youth marries the true bride.

A brother wants to marry his sister. She flees & arrives in the underworld at the house of a witch. There she meets the witch’s daughter who resembles her. Both girls escape from the sorceress by a magic flight, throwing objects behind them. The girls change into birds, & the brother is not able to distinguish them. He pretends he is going to kill himself. The sister betrays herself by an involuntary cry. The brother marries the sorceress’s daughter.

This type combines various introductory episodes with a common main part. Introductory episodes: (1) A boy has been promised (often in return for magic conception) to a demon (devil, giant), or he voluntarily becomes a servant in a demon’s house. The demon orders him to care for two (groups of) animals, to feed the one & to neglect the other. The boy does not follow these instructions & thus makes friends with the abused animal (magic horse). Against the prohibition of the demon, he enters a certain chamber. As a mark of disobedi-ence, his hair turns gold. The boy & the magic horse escape from the demon by a magic flight. (2) A boy (usually the son of a ruler) & a magic foal are close friends . The mother (stepmother) wants to kill the boy. The magic foal warns the boy of her secret murderous attempts. At last the mother demands that the boy or the foal be killed. The boy pretends to agree but asks his father to be allowed to ride the foal one last time. During this ride the foal flies away together with the boy (3) In return for his magic conception, a boy is promised to a demon. On the way to the demon’s house, the boy is forewarned (given instructions for how to kill the demon or to flee). In the rooms of the demon’s house, the boy finds prisoners or corpses (and his hair turns to gold). The boy kills the demon & flees. Main part: The youth covers his golden hair, pretending to be a scaldhead, & takes service in the king’s court as a gardener. (He says nothing except, “I don’t know”.) But the youngest princess sees him in his true form (as a golden-haired knight who destroys & restores the garden three times). She falls in love with Goldener & chooses him as her husband by throwing a golden apple to him. They marry but the angry king banishes the couple to a shabby lodging. The king demands the help of his sons-in-law. Goldener has only a poor kit & is mocked. With the help of his magic horse he achieves various heroic deeds: He obtains the magic remedy (e.g. milk of a bird, water of life) for the king who had grown blind, kills a dragon, defeats a foreign army three times in disguise. He is wounded & is bandaged by the king. Three times he withdraws & is mocked as a fool. Goldener’s identity is revealed (e.g. by wounds, brands) & his true status is recognized. The horse asks to be decapitated & becomes a prince (princess, other person).

A poor youth (orphan, fool, young est of three brothers) sets out with his only heirloom (e.g. rusty sabre ) or with magic objects (stick, flute, etc.) which grateful old people gave him. He becomes the king’s shepherd. The youth is allowed to pasture his livestock on the king’s land but not on the neighboring territory which belongs to three giants (because no one has ever returned from there). The youth disobeys and, with the help of his magic objects (strength), overcomes the three giants one after the other (sometimes their mother, too). In the giants’ lodging the youth finds a magic horse & armour of three different metals (magic weapons, immeasurable wealth, helpful spirits, enchanted persons). The king promises his daughter to whoever rescues her from a (three) dragon(s), wins a tournament, or helps him in battle. The youth, wearing his shining armour & riding his magic horse, succeeds three times. He with-draws & hides until the princess recognizes him as the true champion. The youth marries the princess & becomes king

Classifications: Animal as Helper in the Flight
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A bull (horse, moose, ox, bear, wolf, birds) helps children (an-other person) to escape from their pursuer (devil, witch, robbers). (2) The devil (white wolf) wants to abduct (marry) a princess (girl). A goat puts a straw sheaf in the place of the princess, asks the real princess to climb in a cart, covers her with hay, & tells the devil whom he meets on the way that the princess is at home. The devil grabs the sheaf & takes it to hell. The goat brings the girl home.

Brother & sister leave home (are driven out). The brother kills a number of robbers (devils, giants, dragons) but does not realize that the last one is merely wounded. The sister helps the wounded robber to recover, & he becomes her lover. In order to get rid of the brother, she pretends to be ill & sends him out to get her the milk (liver) of dangerous animals. The brother spares the animals & they follow him (give him a whistle). After the first attempt fails, the sister binds her brother with a silk thread, or she sends him to a magic mill where the animals are kept. When the couple is about to kill the brother, he whistles for the animals. They (break out from the mill and) tear the robber to pieces. The faithless sister is imprisoned (has to repent & to fill a barrel with her tears). The brother takes to the road, rescues a princess from a dragon, & marries her. The sister is brought to the court. She tries to take revenge on her brother by putting a (poisoned) bone into his bed. The brother dies. The animals lick the bone out of his body & he revives. The sister is punished by death.

A woman (queen) who has only sons gives birth to a daughter. The girl first devours the animals, then her brothers & parents, & finally the inhabitants of the village (city). Only one brother escapes. (Or: At a king’s court every night someone devours horses. The elder princes who keep watch fail, but the youngest shoots the monster. He recognizes his baby sister as the cannibal because one of her fingers has been shot off. The youth is driven away [as a liar] or flees [sometimes together with his mother or elder sister].) The youth marries, gives his wife a life token, leaves his dogs (young lions, panther) behind, & returns home. He finds everything devastated. His sister devours his horse & threatens to devour him, too. While she is sharpening her teeth, the youth must play an instrument to prove he is still there. A mouse takes his place & he flees. The youth escapes & climbs three trees in succession which his sister gnaws down. Warned by the life token, his dogs come to save him & kill the cannibal sister.

A poor fisherman (miller) (unwitting-ly) promises his son to a water nix, who makes the fisherman wealthy. The parents keep the child away from the water. When the appointed time comes, the son learns about his father’s promise & flees. On the way the youth divides the carcass of an animal among a lion, a falcon, & an ant (other animals) by taking the animals’ characteristics into consideration. In return he receives from the grateful animals the power to transform himself into their shapes. Using this power he wins a princess as his wife. After winning a battle (while hunting) the youth comes near the water & is seized & pulled down (swallowed) by the water nix. By offering precious objects (three golden apples), his wife tempts the nix to the surface. In exchange for these objects the water nix exhibits her husband: first up to his head, then up to his waist. When the water nix exhibits the husband’s whole body, he changes into a bird & escapes.

Classifications: The Tree That Grows uo tp the Sky
Variation Example: In a king’s yard a tree grows up to the sky. A dragon (giant) living in the tree carries off the princess. The king promises her as a wife to whoever can bring her back. In some variants, the king promises his daughter to whoever brings him healing fruits from the tree. After noble canditates have failed, a young swineherd succeeds in climbing the tree wearing iron boots. In the upper world the youth guards the dragon’s magic horse which tells him (he asks the princess to find out) where the dragon’s power is hidden. The youth kills the dragon, returns to earth together with the princess, & marries her. In some variants, in the upper world the youth watches over the magic horses of a fairy (Tündér Ilona) who gives him clothes of copper, silver, & gold. The fairy falls in love & marries the youth. The youth enters a forbidden chamber & frees a dragon which carries off the fairy.

Introduction: Two brothers live together. The younger works for the elder, who is married. The wife attempts to seduce the younger brother but he refuses her. She complains to her husband that her brother-in-law attacked her. The youth flees from his angry brother.In some variants, this part continues as follows: The fugitive is caught & castrated. After this he lives in a foreign city. A princess falls in love with him & marries him in spite of his mutilation. When the king learns of his son-in-law’s defect, the latter has to flee. He is cured by a supernatural being & is able to return to his wife. Main part: A youth acquires magic objects, among them a magic gift (rusty sword, shirt that imparts strength) from a serpent which he rescued (by theft, by other means). Using these objects, he helps a king to be victorious and, in return, marries a princess. The princess has a lover. She persuades her husband to give her the magic objects (exchanges them). The husband is killed and, as he had requested, his dismembered body is loaded on his horse & carried to the serpent’s castle. The dead youth is resuscitated (by the serpent) & given the power of self-transformation. As a horse with a golden mane he is sold to the king. The princess recognizes the horse as her former husband & orders that it be killed. (On his advice) a maidservant catches drops of its blood which turn into a tree with golden apples. The princess recognizes the tree as her former husband, & orders that it be felled. (On his advice) the maidservant throws a chip into a pond, where it turns into a golden drake. The lover, leaving the sword & shirt behind, tries to catch the drake. The drake becomes a man & uses his magic power to kill his rival & his treacherous wife. He marries the maidservant

A youth takes service as a herdsman with a blind man (couple) whose eyes have been stolen by one or more dragon(s) (giant, witch, fairy). The youth is warned not to take his flock to pasture beyond a certain point, but he disobeys. He meets a dragon & defeats it or tricks it. He retrieves the stolen eyes or receives a magic remedy which enables him to cure the blind man

Classifications: Magnetic Mountain Draws Everything to It
Variation Example: A king’s ship is drawn to a magnetic mountain & smashed to pieces, & the king is washed ashore unconscious. Advised in a dream, the king finds a copper bow with three lead arrows. As instructed he climbs the mountain without looking back or speaking & shoots a copper rider off a copper horse in a temple with copper pillars. The rider falls into the sea, & the king buries the horse. The magnetic mountain begins to sink. A copper man arrives in a copper boat & rescues the king at the last mo-ment.In some variants, the rescuer is a giant bird.

A father apprentices his son to a magician. In order for the son to be released at the end of the apprenticeship, the father has to recognize him. The youth secretly learns how to practice magic & flees, or his father identifies him among a flock of identical doves (other birds) with the help of tokens which the son (an old man) had given to him. The son is released. The father sells the youth successively as a greyhound, an ox, & a horse, but the son tells him not to sell the things that bind them (leash, yoke, bridle). Thus father & son become wealthy. But at last the youth as a horse returns to the magi cian’s in-fluence because, contrary to instructions, the father let the magician take the bridle. So the youth loses his power & is tormented by the magician. Finally the youth succeeds in removing the bridle. He conquers the magician in a transformation combat (they change themselves into hare, fish, bird, etc.) & escapes. At last, transformed into a ring (apple, etc.), he falls into a princess’s lap. When the magician asks for the ring, the princess throws it away & grains of corn fall on the ground. The magician as a rooster is about to eat the corn, but the youth becomes a fox & bites off the rooster’s head. He marries the princess
A sorcerer’s apprentice who reads a verse from a forbidden book calls up a spirit, but cannot make him go away. When the sorcerer reads the verse backwards, the spirit disappears.
A sorcerer who committed evil deeds (e.g. killed a farmer’s sheep) is punished by another sorcerer (e.g. he is bewitched & grows a tail).

Classifications: The Youth Who Wanted to Learn What Fear Is
Variation Example: A youth (fool) who does not know what fear is goes to find it. He tries various frightening experiences without becoming afraid: He is shaved by a barber-ghost, spends the night under a gallows or in a haunted castle, plays with dead persons (bowling, cards), etc. Through his fearless behavior he disenchants a castle (wins a treasure, a promised princess). The youth finally learns what fear is when cold water is thrown on him, fishes are put into his bed while he is asleep, birds fly into his face, his cut-off head is put on backwards, etc. Sometimes sexual: he finds a woman in his bed

A poor soldier spends a night in a haunted house to earn a reward. He is not afraid of dragging chains, cries, falling limbs, etc. The soldier releases a restless spirit from punishment by his fearless behavior (by giving its ill-gotten gains to charity). He discovers a treasure (and may keep part of it for himself).

A fearless youth carries a corpse (several corpses), frightens some robbers by pretending to eat it, & takes away their booty. Using the corpse, he overpowers evil spirits, frees a princess, & marries her.
This type refers to a cycle of related tales. It combines episodes from types 327A, 327B, & 327C.

A (poor) father (persuaded by the stepmother) abandons his children (a boy & a girl) in the forest. Twice the children find their way back home, following scattered pebbles. On the third night, birds eat the scattered peas (bread-crumbs). The children come upon a gingerbread house which belongs to a witch (ogress). She takes them into her house. The boy is fattened, while the girl must do housework. The witch asks the boy to show his finger in order to test how fat he is, but he shows her a bone (stick). When the witch wants to cook the boy, the sister deceives her by feigning ignorance & pushes her into the oven. (The witch’s son finds out that his mother has been killed & pursues the children.) The children escape, carrying the witch’s treasure with them. Birds & beasts (angels) help them across water. They return home.

Seven (three, twelve, thirty) brothers come to an ogre’s house, where they are given night lodging. The ogre intends to cut off the brothers’s heads. In order to recognize his own daughters, the ogre gives them nightcaps (head-scarves). One brother (often the youngest , Thumbling) detects the plan, & all brothers put on the nightcaps of the ogre’s daughters (exchange their caps for the daughters’ head-scarves, change sleeping-places with the daughters). In the night, the ogre cuts off his own daughters’ heads by mistake. The brothers escape.

Classifications: The Devil (Witch) Carries the Hero Home in a Sack
Variation Example: A witch (ogre) entices a boy (conceived by magic, Thumbling) into her bag & carries him away (from his home). By deceiving the witch (putting stones, thorns, mud, etc. in his place), the boy is able to escape twice from the bag. The third time, the witch carries him to her home. He is to be killed by the witch’s daughter. The boy tricks the daughter (by making her show him how he should prepare to be killed), throws her into a pot (burns her in the oven), & serves her as a meal to her family. He taunts the witch, kills her, & returns home (sometimes with the witch’s treasure)

A boy & a girl lose their way in a forest & come to the house of an ogre. The wife protects the children, but the ogre discovers them & intends to hang them. The girl persuades the ogre to show them how it is done. Hanging himself, the ogre begs to be released & promises the children his “kiddelkaddel kar”, a magic cart pulled by (golden) bucks, & much treasure. The children flee & on the way ask three men not to reveal their route. The third man is so much frightened by the ogre that he betrays the children, who hide in a cave. The ogre, not suspecting the children’s presence, lies down to sleep & blocks the way out. The children kill him but cannot leave the cave for three nights until a giant bird eats the ogre’s corpse. Then they return to their parents with the ogre’s treasure.

By imitating the words & voice of his mother who brings him food to the shore each day, a witch tries to catch a fisher boy. She succeeds after she has her tongue made thin by a smith, & carries the boy to her home. When the witch’s daughter tries to bake the boy, he pushes her into the oven. The boy hides in a tree & tells the witch that she has eaten her own daughter (witch finds the daughter’s ring or hair). He is discovered. The witch fells the tree, but at the last moment birds rescue the boy (he makes wings for himself), & he flies home (the witch is trampled by animals, or she bursts while trying to drink the boy’s image reflected in the water).

A witch (devil) catches three brothers – one of them a fool – & fattens them. Her youngest daughter is to roast one of them. The fool pretends he does not know how to lie on the bread paddle & roasts the daughter, whom the old witch eats unwittingly. The same happens to the other two daughters. Then the fool kills the old witch & the three brothers make their way home carrying the witch’s corpse. They climb a tree under which they see robbers. The fool drops the witch’s corpse, the rob bers flee, & the brothers take all their booty.

Introduction (sometimes missing): Three (twelve, thirteen, thirty, etc.) brothers arrive at the house of an ogre (devil). He would kill them in the night, but the smart young est brother saves them by exchanging their caps with those of the ogre’s daughters. The brothers take service at the king’s court. Main part: The jealous brothers claim that the youngest can steal the ogre’s treasures: magic horse, bedspread, carpet, parrot (lamp, sword, silver or golden poultry, musical instruments, etc.). Using tricks the youth gets these objects. At last the brothers claim that the youngest can kidnap the ogre himself. In disguise the youth tells the ogre that the thief died & persuades him to lie down in the coffin to measure it. The youth nails up the coffin, traps the ogre, & is given a princess as his wife. In some variants, the youth sets out to steal from the ogre in order to get revenge for former ill-treatment or to help a friendly king. In some variants, mainly from northern & north-western Europe & the Americas, the protagonist is female.

Two brothers lose their way in a forest (a son leaves his parents’ house & takes a rest while walking through a forest). They are threatened by three giants (trolls) who share only one eye which they put by turns into their foreheads. The brothers steal the giants’ eye & give it back in exchange for a rich reward of gold & silver (magic gifts).

A poor boy named Jack trades his cow for some beans (his mother finds a bean while sweeping the house). One of the beans grows into a giant beanstalk, which Jack climbs to an upper world where he finds the house of a giant. The giant’s wife gives him food & hides him when her husband comes home. The giant smells human flesh but his wife tells him he is mistaken. The giant eats dinner, counts his money, & then falls asleep. Jack steals the money & runs home down the beanstalk. He makes two more trips, stealing the giant’s hen that lays golden eggs & his self-playing harp. The third time, the harp cries out & awakens the giant, who runs after Jack. Jack reaches the bottom of the beanstalk & chops it down. The giant falls to his death, & Jack & his mother have plenty of money.

Classifications: Three Brothers Steal Back Sun, Moon, & Stars
Variation Example: Three brothers go out to retrieve the sun, the moon, & the stars which were stolen by three multi-headed dragons (devils). One of the brothers (often the son of a she-dog) defeats the dragons & releases the celestial lights.

A princess promises to marry whoever can hide himself so well that she cannot find him. Those who fail are beheaded (heads are displayed on stakes). A (poor) youth (youngest of three brothers) undertakes the task Because he had helped some animals (an old man), a fish hides him in his belly, an eagle behind the clouds (the sun), & a fox under the earth. The princess finds him with her magic mirror (magic book) or her perfect sight. The princess gives the youth a fourth trial: He hides behind the magic mirror (under the princess’s seat) or transforms himself (is transformed) & sits as a louse (sticks as a rose) in her hair, etc. The princess cannot find him, so she grants his superiority & marries him.

A smith, who because of poverty (other reasons) sold his soul to the devil (death), gives shelter to Christ & St. Peter during their visit on earth. In reward, three of his wishes shall be fulfilled. St. Peter warns him to wish for a place in paradise, but the smith wants a tree & a bench (chair) to which people stick & a knapsack that draws people into it (a pack of cards with which he shall al-ways win, etc.). When the devil (death) is about to carry the smith away, he sticks to the bench & the tree & has to give the smith more time to live (terminate the contract), or no one would be able to die At last the devil is put into the sack & beaten up (on the anvil). The smith, tired of life, cannot go either to heaven or to hell. He tricks St. Peter by pushing his knapsack into heaven, where it pulls him in (throws his cards inside the gate of heaven & is permitted inside to pick them up).In some variants the trickster-protagonist is an allegorical figure (e.g. Misery, Envy, Poverty) who traps the devil in a tree until the devil promises him immortality. Then he sets the devil free.

A man (son of a woodcutter, smith, fisher-man, soldier) frees an evil spirit from a vessel (bottle) out of curiosity (because he was asked by the spirit). The spirit (which stretches out to an enormous height,) wants to take revenge for being locked for so long, & threatens to kill his rescuer. The man tricks the spirit: He pretends he does not believe that the spirit could grow small again & thus induces him to go back into the vessel. The man stoppers the bottle & the spirit is trapped.In some variants, he is released again in return for a gift (wonder-ful remedy, magic power.

A poor man with many children wants a (just) godfather for his new-born son. He refuses God (saint, devil) & chooses death (angel of death, plague) because he treats everyone alike. As a gift the father (son) receives the magic power of forecasting recovery or death, depending on whether death stands at the head or the foot of the sick person’s bed. Thus the man becomes a famous doctor & grows wealthy. The doctor betrays death (several times): When promised wealth (the princess), the doctor turns the bed & thus saves the life of a person who was supposed to die (in the doctor’s dying hour, death grants him time to say a last Paternoster, but the doctor does not finish the prayer. Death tricks the doctor into finishing the prayer.) In some variants, death shows the man his life-light in the under-world & suddenly extinguishes it. Or the man attempts to lengthen his life by various means (usually without success).

Classifications: Immortality Won through Betrayal of Death
Variation Example: This tale exists in two different forms: (1) An old soldier becomes the doorkeeper for heaven. Death asks him several times whom he should take next. God wants death to take the old people (then people in the middle of their life, then young people in succession). However, the doorkeeper wants to save his parents (wife, children), so he tells death instead to fell firs (beech-trees, oaks). God discovers this deception & shows death whom he should take next. Thus the soldier & his relatives are reunited in heaven. (In some variants, the soldier is banished to hell. Here he delivers a number of souls from purgatory & is chased away. (2) A prince wants to gain immortality. He travels through three different kingdoms, in which the rulers have to perform tasks which must be finished within 600 (800, 1000) years (pulling out a tree, carrying off a mountain, wearing out thousands of sewing needles). During this time death has lost his power. Each time the prince is given magic objects & asked to stay, but he travels on. Finally he arrives at the empire of immortality. After a thousand years he goes to look for his parents. The queen of immortality gives him water of life which he uses to resuscitate the deceased rulers of the three kingdoms. The prince, finding no trace of his former home & family, returns. Pursued by death, he reaches the border of the empire of immortality. In a contest with death, the queen of immortality wins the prince & they live together forever.

A little girl, called “Red Riding Hood” because of her red cap, is sent to her grandmother who lives in the forest & is warned not to leave the path. On the way she meets a wolf. The wolf learns where the girl is going, hurries on ahead, & devours the grandmother (puts her blood in a glass & her flesh in a pot). He puts on her clothes & lies down in her bed. Red Riding Hood arrives at the grandmother’s house. (She has to drink the blood, eat the flesh, & lie down in the bed.) Red Riding Hood doubts whether the wolf is her grandmother & asks him about his odd big ears, eyes, hands, & mouth. Finally the wolf eats Red Riding Hood. A hunter kills the wolf & cuts open his belly. Red Riding Hood & the grandmother are rescued alive. They fill the wolf’s belly with stones; he is drowned or falls to his death. In some variants Red Riding Hood arrives at the grandmother’s house before the wolf. The wolf climbs on the roof to wait until Red Riding Hood leaves. The Grandmother who had boiled sausages asks Red Riding Hood to fill the broth into a big trough in front of the house. Enticed by the smell, the wolf falls from the roof & is drowned in the trough. In an Italian version, a woman who is going to bake cakes sends out her daughter (Caterinella, Caterina, Cattarinetta) to borrow a pan. The lender, an ogre (witch, wolf), asks the girl to bring back some cakes & wine. On her way she eats the cakes, drinks the wine, & replaces them with horse-dung & urine. Angry about the trick, the ogre pursues the girl home & devours her (is not able to get into the house, is tricked out by the girl’s mother).

A girl (woman) disregards the warning of friendly animals (parts of her body) & visits her godmother (grandmother) who is a cannibal. The girl sees many gruesome things (e.g. fence of bones, barrel full of blood, & her godmother with an animal’s head). When the girl tells her godmother what she has seen she is killed (devoured).

Death promises to warn a certain man before he comes to him, so the man lives happily. When death finally comes to take him, the man accuses him not having kept his promise. Death replies that he warned him with the illnesses & infirmities of old age, & takes the man away.

Classifications: Bargain of the Three Brothers & the Devil
Variation Example: Three traveling journeymen (brothers, friends) conclude an agreement with the devil: They receive a large amount of money (purse which will never be empty) on the condition that they pledge themselves always to say the same words, “we three”, “for gold”, “that was right”. The host of an inn kills a rich merchant & accuses the journey-men. Because of their stereotyped answers they seem to confess the offence. The devil rescues them from the gallows. The host is hanged in their place, & the devil is satisfied to take his soul & leave the journeymen alone.

A poor soldier sells his soul to the devil for an immense amount of money (a purse which will never be empty). The soldier’s soul will be released after he has lived for seven years wit-hout washing or combing himself. The soldier helps a poor man, who agrees to let him marry one of his daughters. The two elder daughters scoff at the dirty man, but the youngest daughter agrees to marry him. The soldier leaves her a token (half of a ring or coin). After seven years the bargain is completed. The devil washes & dresses the soldier, & releases him. He returns to his bride as a rich gentleman & is recognized by the token. The envious elder sisters commit suicide. Thus instead of one soul the devil gets two (sometimes more).
